awd_titl_txt: REU Site: NSF REU in Molecular Biosciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of California San Francisco (UCSF), located in San Francisco, CA, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2017- 2019. The focus of the UCSF REU program is the identification, recruitment and preparation of exceptional undergraduates for doctoral training in the Basic Sciences. Students undertake research in the fields of Molecular Biology, Biochemistry, Genetics and Developmental Biology, along with graduate application preparation, and career and professional development programming. An experienced faculty committee selects students based on exceptional academic performance and keen interest in basic research, with a focus on students from disadvantaged backgrounds. 

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. The vast majority of UCSF?s REU alumni pursue graduate education at institutions that are among the most highly competitive and demanding in the country, and every year several students join UCSF programs.


A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://graduate.ucsf.edu/srtp, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Carol Gross at cgrossucsf@gmail.com) or the co-PI (Dr. Hana El-Samad at Helsamad@gmail.com).

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, SAN FRANCISCO, THE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Regents of the University of California, San Francisco

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The NSF REU program at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) provides an intensive research experience and scientific training to undergraduate students who are either historically marginalized and underrepresented (including women, first-generation college, economically disadvantaged, those living with disabilities) or who attend small colleges with limited research opportunities. The NSF REU’s goal is to prepare and encourage its participants to apply, enroll, and succeed in a PhD program in the biomolecular sciences—and ultimately to pursue a career that will increase the scientific and research workforce. 

The NSF REU is the core component of the broader umbrella of UCSF Summer Research Training Programs (SRTP), which allows UCSF to bring in partner funding for additional individual students. These individual students are often sponsored by various UCSF graduate programs. Without the NSF-REU, individual students funded through these partner initiatives would receive a research experience, but without the comprehensive career and professional development programing and community building that is instrumental to student success in their future graduate careers.  

Each student worked closely with a faculty member with whom they met regularly to discuss strategies for experiments, interpreting results, and the pathway to a science career. Additionally, Students were immersed in laboratory research for over 40 hours per week, where they mastered advanced bench skills and learned to design and troubleshoot experiments, and to collect and interpret data. Students attended lab meetings, presented their research to lab groups and peers, and participated in small journal clubs. The final SRTP symposium requires each student to share their results via a poster and oral presentation. To prepare for the symposium, students practiced their scientific writing (creating and revising abstracts, and designing and creating their posters), and improved their communication skills through practice and final presentation of both the poster and the talk.  UCSF’s Graduate Division tracks the career trajectory of SRTP alumni to evaluate persistence in science and the results are published to UCSF’s Graduate Division website (https://graduate.ucsf.edu/srtp-statistics#).  

  

 


Last Modified: 08/09/2023
Modified by: D'anne Duncan
